title: Hedging and Qualification
description: Language for expressing uncertainty and nuanced claims in academic writing

sections.title: Modal Verbs for Hedging
sections.explanation: Modal verbs allow writers to indicate degrees of certainty without making absolute claims.

examples.sentence: This must be the result of selection bias.
This would appear to result from selection bias.
This could/might result from selection bias.

scale: must > will > would > should > may > might > could

sections.title: Hedging Adverbs and Adjectives
sections.explanation: Adverbs and adjectives can soften claims by indicating probability or frequency.

examples.hedged: The data apparently shows a possible correlation.
This theory is arguably somewhat problematic.

sections.title: Reporting Verbs and Distance
sections.explanation: Different reporting verbs create different levels of distance from claims.

sections.title: Impersonal Constructions
sections.explanation: Impersonal constructions remove the writer from direct claims.

examples.personal: I believe this interpretation is correct.
examples.impersonal: It could be argued that this interpretation is valid.
The data suggests that... / It was found that...

exercises.instruction: Hedge the following claim appropriately for academic writing
exercises.sentence: Social media causes depression in teenagers.
exercises.answer: Social media may contribute to depression in some teenagers.
exercises.explanation: Hedge 'causes' with 'may contribute to' and limit scope with 'some'

exercises.question: Which sentence is most appropriately hedged for academic writing?
options: This theory appears to have certain limitations.
This theory might possibly perhaps be wrong.
This theory is probably definitely flawed.
exercises.explanation: Option B uses appropriate hedging without over-hedging or contradictory modifiers

exercises.sentence: The evidence ___ that early intervention is beneficial.
I think this method is unreliable.
exercises.answer: It could be argued that this method may lack reliability.
exercises.explanation: Use 'It could be argued' and 'may lack' instead of personal opinion

exercises.sentence: This definitely might possibly indicate a trend.
